Chapter 3. The Simplex Method

The simplex method is based on the fact that

If a linear programming problem in standard form has an optimal solution, then there exists a basic feasible solution that is optimal.

and searches for an optimal solution by moving from one basic feasible solution to another, along the edges of the feasible set, always in a cost reducing direction. Eventually, a basic feasible solution is reached at which none of the available edges leads to a cost reduction; such a basic feasible solution is optimal and the algorithm terminates.

Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a feasible set in standard form, where A is an m×n matrix such that its m rows are linearly independent.

 

3.1 Optimality conditions

In linear programming, local optimality implies global optimality; this is because we are minimizing a convex function over a convex set.

We concentrate on the problem of searching for a direction of cost decrease in a neighborhood of a given basic feasible solution, and on the associated optimality conditions.

Definition 3.1 A vector d≠0∈Rn is called a feasible direction at x∈P, if there exists θ>0 such that x+θd∈P.

Let x be a basic feasible solution. Denote by B={B1,…Bm} the set of indices of the basic variables, and by N the set of indices of nonbasic variables.

By Theorem 2.4, xi=0 for nonbasic variables i∈N, while xB∈Rm of basic variables is given by

xB=(xB1,…,xBm)=B−1b,

where B=[AB1⋯ABm] is the corresponding (nonsingular) m×m basis matrix.

Choose a nonbasic index j∈N. Let d∈Rn with dj=1 and di=0 for i≠j∈N. If d is a feasible direction, then x+θd∈P for some θ>0. Since x∈P, it follows that Ad=0 and

Ad=∑iAidi=∑k=1mABkdBk+Aj=BdB+Aj.

Thus dB=(dB1,…,dBm)=−B−1Aj∈Rm.

Basic directions and feasible directions

Let x be a basic feasible solution. For a nonbasic index j∈N, the j-th basic direction is defined by the nonzero vector d∈Rn with dB=−B−1Aj, and dj=1 but di=0 for i≠j∈N​.

Is the j-th basic direction always a feasible direction?

  • The equality constraints A(x+θd)=b hold for all θ∈R, since Ad=BdB+Aj=0 by definition.

  • If x is nondegenerate, d is a feasible direction, since xB>0 so that xB+θdB≥0 for sufficiently small θ>0.

  • However, if x is degenerate, d is not always a feasible direction. (∵) If xBk=0 and dBk<0 for some basic variable Bk, then xBk+θdBk<0 for all θ>0; see Figure 3.2.

Reduced costs

Let x be a basic feasible solution and let cB=(cB1,…,cBm). If d is the j-th basic direction for a nonbasic index j∈N, then the rate of cost change along d is given by

cTd=cj+cBTdB=cj−cBTB−1Aj∈R.

Definition 3.2 Let x be a basic solution. For each 1≤j≤n, we define the reduced cost of xj by

c¯j≡cj−cBTB−1Aj.

Since B−1B=B−1[AB1⋯ABm]=I, we have B−1ABk=ek, the k-th column of I. Thus, the reduced cost of a basic variable xBk is always zero, since

c¯Bk=cBk−cBTB−1ABk=cBk−cBTek=cBk−cBk=0.

Theorem 3.1 Let x be a basic feasible solution and let c¯=(c¯1,…,c¯n)∈Rn.

  1. If c¯≥0, then x is optimal.

  2. If x is optimal and nondegenerate, then c¯≥0.

Proof. (1) Let y be an arbitrary feasible solution. For the direction vector d=y−x from x to y, we have cTd=∑i∈Nc¯idi, since

0=Ad=BdB+∑i∈NAidi⟹dB=−∑i∈NB−1Aidi⟹cTd=cBTdB+∑i∈Ncidi=−cBT∑i∈NB−1Aidi+∑i∈Ncidi=∑i∈N(ci−cBTB−1Ai)di=∑i∈Nc¯idi.

However, for i∈N, we have di=yi−xi=yi≥0, since xi=0 (∵ basic solution) and yi≥0 (∵ feasible solution). By assumption c¯i≥0 so that we have cTy−cTx=cTd=∑i∈Nc¯idi≥0.

(2) Suppose that x is nondegenerate and that c¯j<0 for some 1≤j≤n. Since the reduced cost of a basic variable is always zero, we must have j∈N. Since x is nondegenerate, the j-th basic direction is a feasible direction. Thus, by moving in that direction, we obtain feasible solutions whose cost is less than that of x. Therefore, x is not optimal.

Note that Theorem 3.1 allows the possibility that x is a degenerate optimal basic feasible solution, but c¯j<0 for some j∈N.

In order to decide whether a nondegenerate basic feasible solution is optimal, we need only check whether all reduced costs are nonnegative, which is the same as examining the n−m basic directions.

Definition 3.3 A basis matrix B is called optimal if B−1b≥0 and c¯T=cT−cBTB−1A≥0T.

If an optimal basis is found, the corresponding basic solution is feasible (∵ xB=B−1b≥0 and xi=0 for i∈N), satisfies the optimality conditions (∵ c¯≥0), and is therefore optimal by Theorem 3.1.

On the other hand, in the degenerate case, having an optimal basic feasible solution does not necessarily mean that the reduced costs are nonnegative.

 

3.2 Development of the simplex method

A. The simplex method for nondegenerate problems

Let us assume that every basic feasible solution is nondegenerate.

An iteration of the simplex method

  1. We start with a basic feasible solution x and the corresponding basis matrix B.

  2. Compute the reduced costs c¯j≡cj−cBTB−1Aj for all nonbasic indices j∈N.

    • If c¯j≥0 for all j∈N, then x is optimal by Theorem 3.1, and the algorithm terminates.

    • Otherwise, choose some j∈N such that c¯j<0​.

  3. Let d be the j-th basic direction and compute u≡−dB=B−1Aj∈Rm.

    • If u≤0 or d≥0, then x+θd≥0 for all θ≥0. Since c¯j<0, the optimal cost is −∞ and the algorithm terminates.

  4. Otherwise, uk=−dBk>0 for some 1≤k≤m, and the constraint xBk+θdBk≥0 becomes θ≤−xBkdBk=xBkuk. Let θ∗=minuk>0xBkuk>0 (∵ x is nondegenerate) and choose an index 1≤l≤m such that xBlul=θ∗.

  5. Form a new basis matrix B¯ by replacing (the exiting column) ABl with (the entering column) Aj. Then y=x+θ∗d is a new basic feasible solution associated with B¯, since

    yj=θ∗,yBl=0,yBk=xBk−θ∗uk≥0 for k≠l.

Theorem 3.2 The columns AB¯k are linearly independent, and therefore B¯ is a basis matrix.

Proof. Note that ∑k=1mλkAB¯k=0 if and only if

0=∑k=1mλkB−1AB¯k=∑k≠lλkB−1ABk+λlB−1Aj=∑k≠lλkek−λldB

if and only if λk=0 for all 1≤k≤m, since dBl=−ul<0​ by definition.

위의 simplex method iteration에서 새롭게 만들어진 basic feasible solution y​는 degenerate일 수 있다. 하지만 이 경우를 방지하기 위해 모든 basic feasible solution이 nondegenerate라는 가정을 두었다.

Theorem 3.3 Assume that the feasible set is nonempty and that every basic feasible solution is nondegenerate. Then, the simplex method terminates after a finite number of iterations. At termination, there are the following two possibilities:

  • (Step 2) We have an optimal basis B and an associated basic feasible solution which is optimal.

  • (Step 3) We have found d∈Rn satisfying Ad=0, d≥0, cTd=∑i∈Nc¯idi=c¯j<0, and the optimal cost is −∞.

B. The simplex method for degenerate problems

The following new possibilities may be encountered in the course of the algorithm.

  1. If the basic feasible solution x is degenerate, θ∗ can be zero, in which case, y=x.

    • This happens if some basic variable xBl=0 and ul=−dBl>0.

    • Nevertheless, we can still define a new basis B¯ and Theorem 3.2 is still valid.

  2. The new basic feasible solution y can be degenerate, even if θ∗>0.

    • This happens if yBk=xBk−θ∗uk=xBk+θ∗dBk=0 for some k≠l.

Basis changes while staying at y=x (no cost reduction) are not in vain.

  • A sequence of basis changes may lead to the eventual discovery of a cost reducing feasible direction.

  • (Cycling) A sequence of basis changes might lead back to the initial basis, in which case the algorithm may loop indefinitely. (See Section 3.4.)

Pivot Selection

The simplex algorithm has certain degrees of freedom:

  • Entering column Aj in Step 2: We are free to choose any j∈N such that c¯j<0​.

  • Exiting column ABl in Step 4: There may be several choices 1≤l≤m such that xBlul=θ∗.

Regarding the choice of the entering column Aj, the following rules are some natural candidates:

  1. Choose Aj whose reduced cost c¯j<0​ is the most negative.

    • However, the actual cost decrease depends on θ∗c¯j<0.

  2. Choose Aj for which the corresponding cost decrease θ∗|c¯j| is largest.

    • This rule offers the possibility of reaching optimality after a smaller number of iterations.

    • However, the computational burden at each iteration is larger, because we need to compute θ∗ for each column with c¯j<0​.

  3. (Smallest subscript rule) Choose the smallest index j for which c¯j<0.

    • For large problems, even the rule 1 can be computationally expensive.

    • It turns out that cycling can be avoided by following this rule for both the entering and the exiting column. (See the Bland's rule in Section 3.4.)

  4. Refer to the book, p.94 for other pivoting rules.

 

3.3 Implementations of the simplex method

The main difference between alternative implementations lies in the way that B−1Aj are computed and on the amount of related information that is carried from one iteration to the next.

  • Computing the inverse B−1 or solving a linear system BxB=b takes O(m3) operations.

  • Computing the matrix-vector product Bb takes O(m2) operations.

  • Computing the inner product pTb takes O(m) operations.

A. Naive implementation

At the beginning of a typical iteration, we have a set B={B1,…,Bm} of the current basic variables.

  1. Form the basis matrix B and compute the simplex multiplier pT≡cBTB−1 by solving the linear system pTB=cBT​.

  2. Compute the reduced cost c¯j≡cj−cBTB−1Aj=cj−pTAj for j∈N, according to the pivoting rule.

  3. Once an entering column Aj is selected, compute u≡B−1Aj by solving the linear system Bu=Aj​.

  4. Determine θ∗ and the exit column ABl, and then construct the new basic feasible solution y.

The total computational effort per iteration is O(m3+mn).

B. Revised simplex method

An iteration of the revised simplex method

  1. We start with a basic feasible solution x and the corresponding basis matrix B; and furthermore the inverse B−1.​

  2. Compute pT≡cBTB−1 and then compute c¯j=cj−pTAj for all j∈N.

    • If c¯j≥0 for all j∈N, then x is optimal and the algorithm terminates.

    • Otherwise, choose an entering index j∈N such that c¯j<0​​.

  3. Compute u≡B−1Aj.

    • If u≤0, the optimal cost is −∞​ and the algorithm terminates.

  4. Otherwise, let θ∗=minuk>0xBkuk and choose an exiting index 1≤l≤m such that xBlul=θ∗​.

  5. Form the m×(m+1) matrix [B−1|u] and make the last column equal to el by a sequence of elementary row operations. Then the first m columns of the result is B¯−1​.

Since B−1ABk=ek and B−1Aj=u, we have

B−1B¯=[|…|||…|e1…el−1uel+1⋯em|…|||…|]=[1⋯u1⋯0⋮⋱⋮⋱⋮0⋯ul⋯0⋮⋱⋮⋱⋮0⋯um⋯1].

The sequence of elementary row operations is equivalent to left-multiplying B−1B¯ by a certain invertible matrix Q, i.e., QB−1B¯=I or QB−1=B¯−1. Notice that we only use the l-th row of B−1B¯ for elementary row operations to make the l-th column u↦el, i.e., Qu=el.

The total computational effort per iteration is O(m2+mn).

C. The full tableau implementation

The following m×(n+1) matrix is called the simplex tableau.

B−1[b|A]=[|||B−1bB−1A1⋯B−1An|||]

  • The column B−1b=xB, called the zeroth column, contains the values of the basic variables.

  • The j-th column B−1Aj=u, called the pivot column, corresponds to the entering column Aj.

  • The l-th row of the tableau, called the pivot row, corresponds to the exiting column ABl.

  • The element ul>0, called the pivot element, belongs to both the pivot row and the pivot column.

Similar to the revised simplex method, we can compute the updated tableau B¯−1[b|A] by left-multiplying the tableau B−1[b|A] with elementary row operation matrix Q satisfying QB−1=B¯−1​.

Regarding the determination of the exiting column ABl and the step-size θ∗:

  • xBk/uk=(xB⊘u)k is the k-th entry of the element-wise ratio of the zeroth column to the pivot column of the tableau.

  • We only consider those k for which uk>0. The smallest ratio is equal to θ∗ and determines l​.

It is customary to augment the simplex tableau by including a top row, called the zeroth row:

  • The first entry is the negative of the current cost, −cTx=−cBTxB=−cBT(B−1b)​.

  • The rest of the zeroth row is the row vector of reduced costs, c¯T=cT−cBT(B−1A).

  • At the beginning of a typical iteration, the zeroth row is of the form

    [0|cT]−cBTB−1[b|A],

    and with our update rule, the updated zeroth row becomes

    [0|cT]−cB¯TB¯−1[b|A].

    (For the proof, refer to the book, p.100.)

An iteration of the full tableau implementation

  1. We start with a basic feasible solution x and the corresponding basis matrix B; and furthermore the simplex tableau.

  2. Examine c¯T in the zeroth row of the tableau.

    • If c¯T≥0, then x is optimal and the algorithm terminates.

    • Otherwise, choose an entering index j for which c¯j<0​​.

  3. Consider u=B−1Aj, which is the j-th column (the pivot column) of the tableau.

    • If u≤0, the optimal cost is −∞​ and the algorithm terminates.

  4. Otherwise, let θ∗=minuk>0xBkuk and choose an exiting index 1≤l≤m such that xBlul=θ∗​.

  5. (Elementary row operations) Add to each row of the tableau a constant multiple of the l-th row (the pivot row) so that ul​ (the pivot element) becomes one and all other entries of the pivot column become zero.

The total computational effort per iteration is O(mn).

Comparison of the full tableau and the revised simplex methods

The revised simplex method is just a variant of the full tableau method, with more efficient bookkeeping. (See the book, p.106.)

If we consider the smallest subscript pivoting rule, a typical iteration of the revised simplex method might require a lot less work.

  • In the best case, if the first reduced cost c¯j<0, the total computational effort is only O(m2).

  • In the worst case, the cost vector c¯∈Rn is computed, for a total of O(mn) computations per iteration. Since m≤n, the total computational effort is O(m2+mn)=O(mn)​.

The revised simplex method cannot be slower than the full tableau method, and could be much faster during most iterations.

 

3.4 Anticycling: Lexicography and Bland's rule

Lexicography

Lexicographic pivoting rule

  1. Choose an entering column Aj arbitrarily, as long as c¯j<0. Let u=B−1Aj be the j-th column of the tableau.

  2. For each k with uk>0, divide the k-th row of the tableau (including the entry in the zeroth column) by uk and choose the lexicographically smallest row l. Then xBl​ exits the basis.

Note that the lexicographic pivoting rule always leads to a unique choice for the exiting variable.

(∵) If this were not the case, two of the rows in the tableau would have to be proportional. But if two rows of the matrix B−1A are proportional, then rankB−1A<m implies rankA<m, which contradicts our assumption that A has linearly independent rows.

Theorem 3.4 Suppose that the simplex algorithm starts with all the rows in the simplex tableau, other than the zeroth row, lexicographically positive. Suppose that the lexicographic pivoting rule is followed. Then

  1. Every row of the simplex tableau, other than the zeroth row, remains lexicographically positive throughout the algorithm.

  2. The zeroth row strictly increases lexicographically at each iteration.

  3. The simplex method terminates after a finite number of iterations.

Proof. Refer to the book, p.110.

The lexicographic pivoting rule is straightforward to use if the simplex is implemented in terms of the full tableau.

Note that in order to apply the lexicographic pivoting rule, an initial tableau with lexicographically positive rows is required.

  • Assume that an initial tableau is available. Then rename the variables so that the basic variables are the first m ones. This is equivalent to rearranging the tableau so that the first m columns of B−1A are the m unit vectors. The resulting tableau has lexicographically positive rows.

Bland's rule

Smallest subscript pivoting rule

  1. Find the smallest j for which c¯j<0 and have the entering column Aj.

  2. Out of all variables xBk that are tied in the test for choosing an exiting variable xBl, select the one with the smallest k.

The smallest subscript pivoting rule is compatible with an implementation of the revised simplex method.

Under the smallest subscript pivoting rule, it is known that cycling never occurs and the simplex method is guaranteed to terminate after a finite number of iterations.

 

3.5 Finding an initial basic feasible solution

In general, finding an initial basic feasible solution is not easy and requires the solution of an auxiliary linear programming problem.

Auxiliary linear programming problem

We may assume, without loss of generality, that b≥0 by multiplying some of the equality constraint by −1. We introduce y=(y1,…,ym)∈Rm of artificial variables and use the simplex method to solve the auxiliary problem:

minimize1Ty=y1+⋯+ymsubject toAx+y=bx≥0y≥0.

  • Initialization is easy for the auxiliary problem: A basic feasible solution by letting x=0 and y=b and the corresponding basis matrix B=Im​.

  • A feasible solution exists to the original problem if and only if a zero cost solution exists to the auxiliary problem. (⇒) If x is a feasible solution to the original problem, this choice of x together with y=0, yields a zero cost solution to the auxiliary problem. (⇐) If we obtain a zero cost solution to the auxiliary problem, we must have y=0 and thus x​ is a feasible solution to the original problem.

  • Therefore, if the optimal cost in the auxiliary problem is nonzero, the original problem is infeasible.

Driving artificial variables out of the basis

The situation is more complex if (1) the original problem is feasible, (2) the simplex method applied to the auxiliary problem terminates with a feasible solution x∗ to the original problem, but (3) some of the artificial variables are in the final basis. (Since the final value of y is zero, this implies that we have a degenerate basic feasible solution to the auxiliary problem.)

The two-phase simplex method

We can now summarize a complete algorithm for linear programming problems in standard form.

Phase I:

  1. By multiplying some of the constraints by −1, change the problem so that b≥0​.

  2. Introduce artificial variables y1,…,ym, if necessary, and apply the simplex method to the auxiliary problem with cost ∑k=1myk.

  3. If the optimal cost in the auxiliary problem is positive, the original problem is infeasible and the algorithm terminates.

  4. If the optimal cost in the auxiliary problem is zero, a feasible solution to the original problem has been found. If no artificial variable is in the final basis, the artificial variables and the corresponding columns are eliminated, and a feasible basis for the original problem is available.

  5. If the l-th basic variable is an artificial one, examine the l-th entry of the columns B−1Aj for 1≤j≤n. If all of these entries are zero, the l-th row represents a redundant constraint and is eliminated. Otherwise, if the l-th entry of the j-th column is nonzero, apply a change of basis (with this entry serving as the pivot element): The l-th basic variable exits and xj enters the basis. Repeat this operation until all artificial variables are driven out of the basis.

Phase II:

  1. Let the final basis and tableau obtained from Phase I be the initial basis and tableau for Phase II.

  2. Compute the reduced costs of all variables for this initial basis, using the cost coefficients of the original problem.

  3. Apply the simplex method to the original problem.

  • If the problem is infeasible, this is detected at the end of Phase I.

  • If the problem is feasible but the rows of A​ are linearly dependent, this is detected and corrected at the end of Phase I, by eliminating redundant equality constraints.

  • If the optimal cost is equal to −∞, this is detected while running Phase II.

  • Else, Phase II terminates with an optimal solution.

The big-M​ method

The idea is to introduce a cost function of the form cTx+M⋅1Ty, where M is a large positive constant.

  • For a sufficiently large choice of M, if the original problem is feasible and its optimal cost is finite, all of the artificial variables are eventually driven to zero, which takes us back to the minimization of the original cost function.

  • There is no reason for fixing a numerical value for M. We can leave M as an undetermined parameter and let the reduced costs be functions of M. Whenever M is compared to another number (in order to determine whether a reduced cost is negative), M will be always treated as being larger.

 

3.7 Computational efficiency of the simplex method

The number of iterations in the worst case

Theorem 3.5 Consider the linear programming problem of minimizing −xn subject to the constraints ϵ≤x1≤1 and ϵxi−1≤xi≤1−ϵxi−1 for 2≤i≤n. Then

  1. The feasible set has 2n vertices.

  2. The vertices can be ordered so that each one is adjacent to and has lower cost than the previous one.

  3. There exists a pivoting rule under which the simplex method requires 2n−1 changes of basis before it terminates.

The diameter of polyhedra and the Hirsch conjecture

Define d(x,y) between two vertices x,y as the minimum number of jumps (to an adjacent vertex) required to reach y starting from x​.

The diameter D(P) of the polyhedron P is then defined as the maximum of d(x,y) over all pairs of vertices.

We define Δ(n,m) as the maximum D(P) over all bounded polyhedra in Rn that are represented in terms of m inequality constraints. Similarly, Δu(n,m) is defined as the maximum D(P) over all (possibly unbounded) polyhedra in Rn​.

For example, we have Δ(2,m)=⌊m/2⌋ and Δu(2,m)=m−2.

In order to have any hope of developing pivoting rules under which the simplex method require a polynomial number of iterations, we must first establish that Δ(n,m) or Δu(n,m) grows with n and m at the rate of some polynomial.

Hirsch Conjecture Δ(n,m)≤m−n​.

  • [Klee and Walkup, 1967] The Hirsch conjecture is false for unbounded polyhedra, and in particular,

    Δu(n,m)≥m−n+⌊n/5⌋.

    It does not provide any insights as to whether the growth of Δu(n,m)​ is polynomial or exponential.

  • [Kalai and Kleitman, 1993] The worst-case diameter grows slower than exponentially, but the available upper bound grows faster than any polynomial. In particular,

    Δ(n,m)≤Δu(n,m)<m1+log2⁡n=(2n)log2⁡m.

The average case behavior of the simplex method

Among 2m possible linear programming problems, suppose that L of them are feasible.

  • [Haimovich, 1983] Under a rather special pivoting rule, the simplex method requires no more than n/2 iterations, on the average over those L feasible problems.
